custom_item_2.description: OpenStack Identity - user/group ownership of config files set to keystone - /etc/keystone/keystone.conf
custom_item_2.info: Configuration files contain critical parameters and information required for smooth functioning of the component. If an unprivileged user, either intentionally or accidentally modifies or deletes any of the parameters or the file itself then it would cause severe availability issues causing a denial of service to the other end users. Thus user and group ownership of such critical configuration files must be set to that component owner.
custom_item_2.solution: Set user and group ownership of these config files to keystone

custom_item_9.description: OpenStack Identity - strict permissions set for Identity configuration files - /etc/keystone/keystone.conf
custom_item_9.info: It is recommended to set strict access permissions for configuration files. 640 or better.
custom_item_9.solution: Set permissions are to 640 or stricter

custom_item_16.info: OpenStack components communicate with each other using various protocols and the communication might involve sensitive or confidential data. An attacker may try to eavesdrop on the channel in order to get access to sensitive information. Thus all the components must communicate with each other using a secured communication protocol like HTTPS.
custom_item_16.solution: Set the value of parameter enable under [ssl] section in /etc/keystone/keystone.conf to True

custom_item_17.description: OpenStack Identity - Identity uses strong hashing algorithms for PKI tokens
custom_item_17.info: MD5 is a weak and depreciated hashing algorithm. It can be cracked using brute force attack. Identity tokens are sensitive and need to be protected with a stronger hashing algorithm to prevent unauthorized disclosure and subsequent access.
custom_item_17.solution: Set the value of parameter hash_algorithm under [token] section in /etc/keystone/keystone.conf to SHA256

custom_item_18.description: OpenStack Identity - max_request_body_size set to default
custom_item_18.info: The parameter max_request_body_size defines the maximum body size per request in bytes. If the maximum size is not defined, the attacker could craft an arbitrary request of large size causing the service to crash and finally resulting in Denial Of Service attack. Assigning the maximum value ensures that any malicious oversized request gets blocked ensuring continued availability of the component.
custom_item_18.solution: Set value of parameter max_request_body_size in /etc/keystone/keystone.conf is set to default (114688) or some reasonable value based on your environment

custom_item_19.description: OpenStack Identity - Disable admin token in /etc/keystone/keystone.conf
custom_item_19.info: The admin token is generally used to bootstrap Identity. This token is the most valuable Identity asset, which could be used to gain cloud admin privileges.
custom_item_19.solution: Ensure 'admin_token' under [DEFAULT] section in /etc/keystone/keystone.conf is disabled

custom_item_20.description: OpenStack Identity - Disable admin token in /etc/keystone/keystone-paste.ini
custom_item_20.info: The admin token is generally used to bootstrap Identity. This token is the most valuable Identity asset, which could be used to gain cloud admin privileges.
